data.title: Nice library
data.text: The is the old courthouse at the corner of Broad Street and Meeting Street. The main courthouse is next door. The entrance is on the back side and you do have to go through metal detectors so don't take anything that will be confiscated. There is a law library on the second floor that is beautiful. This is still a working area witht he probate court offices so you won't always be allowed in certain areas. There is a courtroom on the second floor, but it was in use so you are not allowed in and need to be quiet. The history is interesting.

data.title: Good historical visit
data.text: An operational courthouse and museum wrapped into one.  Free!  Not that much to see though.  No tour, no guide, a little video to watch but honestly not a big deal.  Nice short historical visit.

data.title: Worth A Stop
data.text: The courthouse is next to a park we were in. We walked in to realize they have a black and white slide show on the main floor. History at it's best. Make sure to walk into the bathroom which is retro and immaculate.

data.title: Hisstory , well preserved rooms  and a law library worth seeing.
data.text: This historic courthouse is open to the pubic free of charge. You will go thr5ough a metal detector as the 3rd floor is an active court. The first 2 floors however are yours to wander and will really transport you back in time. The walls abound with important people of the earliest beginnings of Charleston.  This is a grand building, but my personal favorite was the law library. Wall to ceiling books, wood paneled, and a second story. Leather bound books in glass cases, brass railings It is just a very impressive space.

data.title: Neat historic building
data.text: While visiting Charleston, we were told to check out the County Courthouse.  There were interesting paintings and beautiful rooms and a chance to get out of the humidity for a while! :)

data.title: Nice stop to get out of the heat!
data.text:
As we were exploring the streets of Charleston we saw a sign that said Visitors Welcome. So we went inside. It was so great to get into the A/C and also find a nice bathroom.
It is free and there are some fun rooms to look at and explore. About 30 minutes is all you need. You will have to go through a metal detector to get inside. Sometimes court is going on and you cannot go upstairs.

data.title: Charming Building
data.text: Cool old historic building. Check out the old post office museum in it too. Just a few blocks to walk from the Market area.

data.title: Very Historic Free Self Walking Tour
data.text: All staff from the Security to individual offices are very helpful and friendly. They do not make you feel dumb when you ask a question even though they have probably heard it a million times. The building is historic with lots of mementos of days gone by as well as newer art work. It is worth taking a trip just to tour the building.

data.title: A step back in time
data.text: We were in Old Charleston when we walked past the old courthouse...originally the State Supreme Court. There are some very cool photos and the original court room is perfectly restored. The old law library is still in tact and we enjoyed seeing the old law books (my wife is an attorney), It is still a working building for some offices. It's free to enter too!

data.title: Historic tourists- listen up! These walls are lined in history- Charleston's Historic Courthouse
data.text:
Sitting on one of the "Four Pillars of Justice," at the corner of Meeting and Broad Streets, the Historic Courthouse harkens back to Charleston's provincial roots.  The 'Historic Court House' sits upon the location of the original, which partially burned.  The Colonial SC Commons House of Assembly met here (on the 2nd floor) to run the business of the colony and eventually discuss how to handle situations like Stamp Act (amongst others, which eventually influenced the SC transition from Colony to Statehood.)  A kiosk display on the first floor details  the history of the site.  The physical walls of the building are lined with copies of portraits of people who had a positive impact in South Carolina, all collected into one place. Honestly, a better presentation could easily be managed here by framing and labeling each portrait  (not just tacked paper to the wall) with a  short biography attached beneath, highlighting each person's significance.  For example, when I visited, a replica  of Alan Ramsay's  portrait of 'Peter Manigault', Speaker of the Commons House of Assembly 1765- 1772 (Joseph Manigault's father -  see Joseph Manigault House and the Charleston Museum)  was hanging in the stairwell, adjacent to the Palladian window, but it was not labeled.  If you know nothing about Mr. Manigault, you'd pass it by thinking nothing of it, or 'Who was that?")    

Visitors are permitted to the second floor to have a look around.  Here you will find  more historic portraits, 2 still- in-use court rooms which can be walked through, and a gorgeous library (for display).  

The architecture of the building is lovely, the Palladian windows highlighting the back wall.

I highly, highly recommended for a stop inside the Historic Courthouse, especially if you are doing a historic tour of Charleston. The history and architecture of the building are wonderful! it is definitely worth your while!

Plan for 20 min- half hour.

data.title: Cool
data.text: I didn't go inside, but enjoyed the architecture of the outside.  There are so many wonderful buildings downtown, and this is one of them.

data.title: Such history
data.text: So much history here.  It is worth a quick look inside.
